member.summary: Called when a state is removed from game (popped from stack).

member.summary: Functions to call for this state when it is not the active state.

member.summary: Manages components of this game state.

member.summary: Returns true if this State is at the top of the State stack.

member.name: P:Spooker.GameStates.State.IsOverlay
member.summary: Overlay states are active when on top of the stack. The following non-overlay state will also be active.

member.name: M:Spooker.Network.NetworkAgent.SendMessage(Lidgren.Network.NetConnection)
member.summary: Sends off _outgoingMessage and then clears it for the next send. Defaults to UnreliableSequenced for fast transfer which guarantees that older messages won't be processed after new messages.

member.name: M:Spooker.Network.NetworkAgent.SendMessage(Lidgren.Network.NetConnection,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sends off _outgoingMessage and then clears it for the next send. Defaults to UnreliableSequenced for fast transfer which guarantees that older messages won't be processed after new messages. If IsGuaranteed is true it uses ReliableSequenced which is safer but much slower.
member.param: If set to true is guaranteed.

member.name: T:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.Particle
member.summary: particles are the little bits that will make up an effect. each effect will be comprised of many of these particles. They have basic physical properties, such as position, velocity, acceleration, and rotation. They'll be drawn as sprites, all layered on top of one another, and will be very pretty.

member.summary: Position of particle

member.summary: Velocity of particle

member.name: T:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleEmitter
member.summary:
Helper for objects that want to leave particles behind them as they move around the world. This emitter implementation solves two related problems:
If an object wants to create particles very slowly, less than once per frame, it can be a pain to keep track of which updates ought to create a new particle versus which should not.
If an object is moving quickly and is creating many particles per frame, it will look ugly if these particles are all bunched up together. Much better if they can be spread out along a line between where the object is now and where it was on the previous frame. This is particularly important for leaving trails behind fast moving objects such as rockets.
This emitter class keeps track of a moving object, remembering its previous position so it can calculate the velocity of the object. It works out the perfect locations for creating particles at any frequency you specify, regardless of whether this is faster or slower than the game update rate.

member.name: M:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleEmitter.#ctor(Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSystem,System.Single,Spooker.Vector2)
member.summary: Constructs a new particle emitter object.

member.name: M:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleEmitter.Update(Spooker.Time.GameTime,Spooker.Vector2)
member.summary: Updates the emitter, creating the appropriate number of particles in the appropriate positions.

member.name: P:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleEmitter.Position
member.summary: Gets the location of the emitter. To change locations, pass a new value in to Update.

member.name: T:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.AccelerationMode
member.summary: Used to specify the method of acceleration for a particle system.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.AccelerationMode.None
member.summary: The particle system does not use acceleration.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.AccelerationMode.Scalar
member.summary: The particle system computes the acceleration by using the MinAccelerationScale and MaxAccelerationScale values to compute a random scalar value which is then multiplied by the direction of the particles.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.AccelerationMode.EndVelocity
member.summary: The particle system computes the acceleration by using the EndVelocity value and solving the equation vt = v0 + (a0 * t) for a0. See ParticleSystem.cs for more details.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.AccelerationMode.Vector
member.summary: The particle system computes the acceleration by using the MinAccelerationVector and MaxAccelerationVector values to compute a random vector value which is used as the acceleration of the particles.

member.name: T:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings
member.summary: Settings class describes all the tweakable options used to control the appearance of a particle system. Many of the settings are marked with an attribute that makes them optional so that XML files can be simpler if they wish to use the default values.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MinNumParticles
member.summary: Sets the minimum range of particles used for each "effect" when the particle system is used.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MaxNumParticles
member.summary: Sets the maximum range of particles used for each "effect" when the particle system is used.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.TextureFilename
member.summary: Name of the texture used by this particle system.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MinDirectionAngle
member.summary: MinDirectionAngle and MaxDirectionAngle are used to control the possible directions of motion for the particles. We use degrees instead of radians for the settings to make it easier to construct the XML. The ParticleSystem will convert these to radians as it needs.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MaxDirectionAngle
member.summary: MinDirectionAngle and MaxDirectionAngle are used to control the possible directions of motion for the particles. We use degrees instead of radians for the settings to make it easier to construct the XML. The ParticleSystem will convert these to radians as it needs.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MinInitialSpeed
member.summary: MinInitialSpeed and MaxInitialSpeed are used to control the initial speed of the particles.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MaxInitialSpeed
member.summary: MinInitialSpeed and MaxInitialSpeed are used to control the initial speed of the particles.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.AccelerationMode
member.summary: Sets the mode for computing the acceleration of the particles.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.EndVelocity
member.summary: Controls how the particle velocity will change over their lifetime. If set to 1, particles will keep going at the same speed as when they were created. If set to 0, particles will come to a complete stop right before they die. Values greater than 1 make the particles speed up over time. This field is used when using the AccelerationMode.EndVelocity mode.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MinAccelerationScale
member.summary: Controls the minimum acceleration for the particle when using the AccelerationMode.Scalar mode.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MaxAccelerationScale
member.summary: Controls the maximum acceleration for the particle when using the AccelerationMode.Scalar mode.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MinAccelerationVector
member.summary: Controls the minimum acceleration for the particle when using the AccelerationMode.Vector mode.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MaxAccelerationVector
member.summary: Controls the maximum acceleration for the particle when using the AccelerationMode.Vector mode.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.EmitterVelocitySensitivity
member.summary: Controls how much particles are influenced by the velocity of the object which created them. AddParticles takes in a Vector2 which is the base velocity for the particles being created. That velocity is first multiplied by this EmitterVelocitySensitivity to determine how much the particles are actually affected by that velocity.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MinRotationSpeed
member.summary: Range of values controlling how fast the particles rotate. Again, these values should be in degrees for easier XML authoring.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MaxRotationSpeed
member.summary: Range of values controlling how fast the particles rotate. Again, these values should be in degrees for easier XML authoring.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MinLifetime
member.summary: Range of values controlling how long a particle will last.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MaxLifetime
member.summary: Range of values controlling how long a particle will last.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MinSize
member.summary: Range of values controlling how big the particles are

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.MaxSize
member.summary: Range of values controlling how big the particles are

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.Gravity
member.summary: Controls the gravity applied to the particles. This can pull particles down to simulate gravity, up for effects like smoke, or any other direction.

member.name: F:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings.BlendMode
member.summary: Alpha blending settings. Our default gives us a BlendState equivalent to BlendState.AlphaBlend which is suitable for many particle effects.

member.summary: Creates new instance of ParticleSettings class

member.summary: Creates new instance of ParticleSettings class from file

member.summary: Creates new instance of ParticleSettings class from file

member.name: T:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSystem
member.summary: Particle system.

member.name: M:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSystem.#ctor(Spooker.Core.GameWindow,Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The host for this particle system.
Settings used for this particle system.

member.name: M:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSystem.#ctor(Spooker.Core.GameWindow,Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSettings,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The host for this particle system.
Settings used for this particle system.
The initial number of particles this system expects to use. The system will grow as needed, however setting this value to be as close as possible will reduce allocations.

member.name: M:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSystem.PickRandomDirection
member.summary: PickRandomDirection is used by AddParticle to decide which direction particles will move.

member.name: M:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSystem.AddParticles(Spooker.Vector2,Spooker.Vector2)
member.summary: AddParticles's job is to add an effect somewhere on the screen. If there aren't enough particles in the freeParticles queue, it will use as many as it can. This means that if there not enough particles available, calling AddParticles will have no effect.
member.param: Where the particle effect should be created
A base velocity for all particles. This is weighted by the EmitterVelocitySensitivity specified in the settings for the particle system.

member.name: M:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSystem.InitializeParticle(Spooker.Graphics.Particles.Particle,Spooker.Vector2,Spooker.Vector2)
member.summary: InitializeParticle randomizes some properties for a particle, then calls initialize on it. It can be overriden by subclasses if they want to modify the way particles are created. For example, SmokePlumeParticleSystem overrides this function make all particles accelerate to the right, simulating wind.
member.param: the position on the screen that the particle should be
The base velocity that the particle should have

member.name: M:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSystem.Update(Spooker.Time.GameTime)
member.summary: overriden from DrawableGameComponent, Update will update all of the active particles.

member.name: M:Spooker.Graphics.Particles.ParticleSystem.Draw(Spooker.Graphics.SpriteBatch,Spooker.Graphics.SpriteEffects)
member.summary: overriden from DrawableGameComponent, Draw will use ParticleSampleGame's sprite batch to render all of the active particles.

member.summary: returns the number of particles that are available for a new effect.
